div.head: LAND VALUES IN EGYPT.
div.p: We call attention to an article on the above subject by Mr. Lang Anderson in the last Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce, and which we reproduce in today's issue. Mr. Anderson is optimistic, but when we follow out his closely-reasoned and lucid summary of the causes why land should have increased in value, his conclusion seems perfectly logical—that prices are not inflated, that the rise has been based on very sound conditions, and that before long land in a this country will be sold on 20 years' purchase of the annual revenue, that is,
Sunlight
Clothes will last longer if SUNLIGHT SOAP is used.
Makes Linen Whiter and Coloured things Brighter.
FULL DIRECTIONS ON WRAPPER.
Soap

on a basis of 5 % return for capital invested. The Financial Adviser, in his Note on the Budget for 1905, says "the country has advanced in prosperity by leaps and bounds, but it is wise to remember that the almost sensational results of the last few years are due, in part at least, to adventitious causes on the permanent continuance of which it would be imprudent to count." Mr. Lang Anderson's article shows no fear for the future, for discarding altogether the high price of cotton during the last two or three years, and taking as a basis of valuation of land cotton at P.T. 250 for the fellah's seed kantar, he shows that land is after all still at a moderate price. The memory of the great Australian land crash, now a matter of a good few years ago, makes people at times shake their heads over the "boom" in Egyptian land, but Mr. Lang Anderson very clearly points out that the economic condition of the fellah proprietor makes any land crisis in Egypt a remote contingency. The article is one well worthy of attention, based as it is on the thorough knowledge of land questions in Egypt. We would remark that whilst land may be reasonable in price, a note of warning has to be sounded against the tendency to force Land Company shares to inflated values. Not everybody can buy land and manage it properly, and therefore there is a strong temptation to invest in land companies, but would-be purchasers should not too much discount the future by paying higher prices for shares than is warranted.
MACEDONIA
ADDITIONAL GENDARMERY OFFICERS.
CONSTANTINOPLE, December 28.
The Porte, under strong pressure, has agreed to the demand of the Powers for the appointment of 23 additional European gendarmery officers in Macedonia. (Reuter.)
AUSTRIA-HUNGARY.
IMPENDING CABINET CRISIS.
VIENNA, December 28.
In consequence of Herr von Koerber's state of health, an early Ministerial crisis is imminent. (Havas.)
FRENCH PARLIAMENT..
PARIS, December 28.
The Chamber of Deputies and the Senate have voted a provisional douzième.
The session is closed. (Havas.)
FRENCH ARMY.
"INFORMING" METHODS.
PARIS, December 28.

The Minister of War has addressed a circular to the military Governors and Commanders of the Army Corps, directed against inadmissible methods of obtaining information. Officers have been required to justify actions which were purely matters of conscience. These methods should be severely punished. The army must devote the whole of its energies in preparing to defend the country, and must not be distracted by party strifes. (Reuter.)
RUSSIAN REFORM
MOVEMENT.
"STOP THE WAR" BANQUET.
GROWING FERMENT.
CONSTITUTION THE REMEDY.
ST. PETERSBURG, December 28.

A Banquet. at which 1,000 persons were present, was held in the Pavloff Hall here in order to protest against the war. The day chosen was the anniversary of the revolution in 1825. The speakers declared that it was hopeless to look for the restoration of peace so long as Russia had no constitution. They were vociferously applauded. (Reuter.)
ST. PETERSBURG, December 28.

Yesterday evening's assembly, which was widely representative and called a banquet in order to evade the prohibition of meetings, was only concluded at 2:30 in the morning. Speeches, and a most earnest resolution denounced the war and demanded a legislature elected by means of ballot. (Reuter.)
EXCITED ZEMSTVOS MEETING.
Moscow, December 28.
The meeting of the Zemstvos of the Province of Moscow was a very excited one. Demonstrations were made in the streets where thousands, who were unable to obtain admission, cheered noisily.
Moscow, December 28.

The Zemstvos adjourned indefinitely after adopting a resolution declaring that the delegates were so concerned at yesterday's communique that they were unable to conduct their business with the necessary calm. (R.)
ST. PETERSBURG, December 28.
The President and 40 members of the Zemstvos of Chernigoff have resigned in consequence of the communiqué. The Zemstvos has, therefore, been dissolved. (Reuter.)
Moscow, December 28.
Prince Galitzin, Mayor of Moscow, has resigned. These and other incidents indicate growing ferment. (Reuter.)
SCIENCE AND A CONSTITUTION.
Moscow, December 28.
At a meeting of the University Professors and leading savants, it was unanimously declared that no progress in science was possible without the establishment of a constitutional regime. (Reuter.)
THE TSAR'S RESCRIPT.
ST. PETERSBURG, December 28.

The decree is so worded that it is variously regarded as conceding much and conceding nothing beyond vague promises. Meanwhile the unqualified language of the Government communiqué causes deep disappointment to the Reformers. (Reuter.)
JAPANESE OFF HONG KONG. :
Hong Kong, December 28.
A large Japanese cruiser has arrived at Amoy, and two others are off here. (Reuter.)
DUTCH NEUTRALITY.
The Hague, December 28.

It is pointed out that the neutrality of Sabaug will be maintained by two battleships, two armoured cruisers, a gunboat and 4 destroyers which are now there, while 3 other battleships are in the archipelago. Two war ships are leaving Holland to reinforce the squadron. (Reuter.)
FIRTH OF FORTH.
NATAL BASE PROJECT SHELVED.
London, December 28.
It is reported that the idea of a naval base in the Firth of Forth has been shelved, as Sir J. Fisher desires to devote all the available money for the construction of new ships. (R.)
AMERICAN COTTON.
EFFECT OF BUREAU CENSUS.
NEW YORK, December 28.

The cotton here fell between 30-35 points, and at New Orleans between 47-55 points, owing to the census of the Agricultural Bureau to the 13th inst. showing 11,848,113 commercial bales ginned, compared with 8,747,669 last season. (Reuter.)
WINDSOR HOTEL
Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea, Central position. Under English management. B1.11.904
PORT ARTHUR
DESPERATE FIGHTING.
GEN STOESSEL INJURED
Tokio, December 28.

Further lists have been published showing 51 officers killed and 142 wounded, but it is not stated where and when. It is believed the same indicate desperate fighting at Port Arthur, which has not yet been reported.
General Stoessel has been injured by a fall from his horse. General Smirnoff has been wounded. (Reuter.)
LOCAL AND GENERAL
PARADE.- The Egyptian troops in Cairo paraded on the Mohamed Aly-square this morning
SUICIDE.--No trace has been found of Mr. Bensilum, whose disappearance we recently chronicled.
STRAY AND OWNERLESS Dogs found in the Boulac district of Cairo to-morrow morning will be poisoned by the police.
A FIRE broke out in a hatter's shop in Mohamed Aly-square yesterday but was speedily extinguished, before much damage was done.
AGRICULTURAL BANK.--This morning 800 mortgage deeds were entered at the Mixed Courts, Alexandria, by the Agricultural Bank of Egypt.
WATCH-NIGHT SERVICES. - In St. Mark's, Alexandria, and in All Saint's, Ramleh, a short service will be held, beginning at 11.30 p.m., on Saturday (New Year's Eve).
H. M.'s FIRST-CLASS CRUISER "CRESSY” arrived at Suez from the China station on Tuesday evening, and entered the Canal early yesterday morning bound to Malta.

Suez CANAL.-During the 3 days, 24th, 25th and 26th inst., 53 vessels passed through the Canal. Of these, 37 were British, 8 German, 1 Dutcb, 1 French, 1 Austrian, 3 Italian, 1 Norwegian, 1 Greek, the receipts being frs.1,451,445.32. From the 1st to the 26th inst., the total receipts amounted to frs. 9,312,871.78.

ZAGAZIG DOUBLE MURDER.— The Mufti of Sharkieh has confirmed the death sentence passed upon the murderers of Mme Galli and Mme. Benetti, who were killed at Zagaziy on the night of August 23. The two principals are condemned to death, the other three to hard labour for life.

New YEAR CALLS.-Mr. R. Stabile, vice-president of the Maltese Benevolent Society, has sent the society a contribution of £10, and Dr. Hadjes Bey P.T. 60, as a dispensation from paying New Year calls. We have received £1 from Mr. Heinrich Hoffmann for the funds of the Anti-Tuberculosis League, and Mr. Hugo Lindemann has sent £1 to the Rudolph Home.

E. T. C. “At HOME" AT SUEZ.-The Eastern Telegraph Company's staff mess entertained the residents of Suez to a delightful dance on Monday last. The quarters, which were beautifully decorated with flags and flowers and illuminated by electric light, presented a brilliant aspect. Dancing was kept up till a late hour, to the strains of a fine string band and the whole evening was most enjoyable.

ACTION AGAINST NEWSPAPERS: --- Judgment in the case brought by Youssef Bey Saddik against the Daira of Prince Mohamed Ibrabim and the Journal du Caire and the Reforme will be given on Monday next. The conclusions of the "Ministère Public" were delivered on Monday in the 1st Mixed Civil Chamber at Cairo. The "Ministère" asked for the rejection of the plaintiff's claim for L.E. 35,000 damages.

SEASONABLE WEATHER.-Everybody is complaining of the cold, both in Cairo and Alexandria, and that they are quite sincere in their complaints is shown by the beggarly array of empty seats that appeal unavailingly to their ordinary patrons outside all the most popular cafés. Overcoats and cloaks are the order of the day and the sunny side of the streets is now the favorite one. And only a month ago the airiest costumes were all we needed!

The Late MR. HENDERSON. --We understand that the business at Farascour, Bortah, Mansourah, Takla, and other places in the Delta, of the late Mr. John Kinloch Henderson, who died recently at Alexandria, will be carried on by his sons, Mr. J. Ambrose and Mr. Daniel Henderson, under the style of "Henderson Brothers.” It will be remembered that Mr. J. K. Henderson returned in November from Europe, and being in indifferent health, remained with his family at Alexandria, instead of proceeding at once to Mansourah. The liver disease from which he suffered unfortunately terminated fatally. His loss will be mourned by a large circle of friends, whom Mr. Henderson had drawn round him during his residence of 35 years in Egypt. We take this opportunity of offering to his widow and family our heartfelt sympathy.
THE DAIRA, SANIEH.
BUDGET FOR 1905.

A meeting of the Superior Council of the Daira Sanieh Administration, under the presidency of Mazloum Pasha, was held this morning at the Ministry of Finance. With the exception of the French Controller, who has not yet returned from leave, all the members were present. The proposed Budget for 1905 was explained in detail by Crookshank Pasha, British Controller, and unanimously approved. The total estimated receipts for the year amount to L.E. 1,288,499 and the expenditure to L.E. 561,779, leaving a magnificent surplus in the hands of the Controllers of L.E. 726,720. The surplus for the present year (1904) will be close on L.E. 345,000, so that the result of the work of the last two years' existence of the administration which will be liquidated in October, (1905), will be a surplus of over one million Egyptian pounds towards the reduction of the Debt, of which the amountatpresentoutstanding is £4,463,580.
THE KHEDIVE.
The Khedive, who has been paying a visit to his estates on the Ismailia Canal, returned to Koubbeh yesterday evening.
This morning, his Highness proceeded to Abdeen Palace and presided at a Council of Ministers.

COUNCIL OF MINISTERS. At this morning's meeting of the Council of Ministers the promotions and decorations which are to be bestowed on the occasion of the approaching anniversary of the Khedive's accession were discussed.
KAFR AMMAR COLLISION.

The great damage inflicted on the dining-car in the recent collision is explained by the fact that the light brake van was flung off its frame by the shock and crashed in upon the dining-car, destroying all the upper works and falling on the solid frame of the last-mentioned car. We hear that the Board of Trade have several times protested against the practice of mixing up light and heavy waggons on the same train, on the ground that the former in the case of a collision become veritable missiles.
We are glad to hear that the condition of the injured shows a steady improvement.
IRRIGATION DEPT.
Mr. R. C. Moser, 1st class surveyor of contracts to the 3rd Circle, has been transferred to the 2nd Circle.
Mr. S. R. Wallace, 3rd class surveyor of contracts, has been transferred from the 2nd to the Zitta Circle.
THE ALEXANDRIA FIRE.
It is estimated that from seven to eight millions of cigarettes were destroyed by the recent fire.
A largely attended open-air auction was held to-day of the perishable goods from Walker and Meimarachi's stores. Good prices were realised.
ZIZINIA THEATRE.

La Cabrera was given on Tuesday and yesterday evening, a portion of Don Pasquale being given on the former and Rigoletto on the latter evening. The performance of these two operas met with the same success as on the previous occasions.

La Cabrera was the opera chosen for the prize of 50,000 frs. by the members of the syndicate, composed of about 30 composers, amongst whom figured an eminent French composer, at the last "Concours Suuzoim" at Milan. Having received the above official approbation it would be superfluous to enlarge on the intrinsic value of the play. No attempt is therefore made in this respect. We will only state that although the interpretation of the title role by Signa Pinto was everything that could be desired, and that she was ably seconded by Signor Pirari, yet the public did not seem to greet the opera with the merited acclamation. This, we dare say, will come when it is heard one or twice more. The pretty intermezzo (which called for much applause) and the passionate nature of the music somewhat remind one of the immortal Cavalleria and the La Navaraisse.
ABBAS HELMY THEATRE.

Offenbach's Barba Bleu was given last night at this theatre before a delighted audience, who were unsparing in their applause of what was an all-round excellent performance. The singing was splendid, the music entrancing, the costumes beautiful, and the mise-en-scene good. Signa. Suarez, it goes without saying, again distinguished herself as Giorgetta, Sig. Accouci was good as Bluebeard, Sig. Forconi entertaining as the King, and Sig. Gravina excruciatingly funny as the alchemist. The other artistes all did well in their respective roles
We hear that the company are rehearsing an Italianised version of The Mikado, the performance of which will be looked forward to with interest by the English colony.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Messageries Maritimes mail steamer "Salazie" arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria, yesterday at 2 a.m.

ALEXANDRIA.

PRINCE LEOPOLD.
VISIT TO KHARTOUM.

H. R. H. Prince Leopold of Battenberg and party, who spent Christmas at the Cataract Hotel, Assouan, have left for Khartoum, where His Royal Highness intends to make a short visit and will afterwards return to the Cataract Hotel for the remainder of the season.
THE HOLY CARPET.

Two Companies of the 16th Battalion, accompanied by the Infantry Band, will parade at El Khoronfish at 3 p.m. to-morrow to escort, at 3:50 p.m., the Holy Carpet from there via El Nabassin, to the end of Gamalia-road, near El Sibil, where the Mahmal will be waiting, which they will also accompany, as an escort, to the Mastaba, on Mohamed Aly-square. The band will remain at the Mastaba for the reception of visitors till 8 p.m.

The troops in Cairo will proceed to Mohamed Aly-square on Saturday next, 31st inst., at 9.30 a.m., for the reception of the Holy Carpet and of his Highness the Khedive, and afterwards to escort the Holy Carpet to the Mosque of El Hussein. The troops will take up the following formation :-Infantry, in line without intervals between companies; intervals between battalions 3 paces. Artillery, in line at half intervals on the right flank of Infantry, Cavalry and Maxim Section, in line on the right flank facing inwards. 8th Battalion, on the left flank facing inwards.

The Officer Commanding Artillery will arrange for the necessary guns to be at Mohamed Aly square at 9.30 a.m. on Saturday next, to fire the usual salutes for the Holy Carpet, and on the arrival and departure of the Khedive. On the occasion of the reception of the Holy Carpet on Saturday next, Government offices will be closed and the day observed as a general holiday.
ACCESSION DAY REVIEW.

Residents and visitors who are desirous of seeing the review held at the Polygon, Abbassieh, on January 8, 1905, in honour of H.H. the Khedive's accession, can obtain tickets by applying to the D.A.A.G., War Office, Egyptian Army. It is requested that such application be marked on the cover "Residents-Carriage Enclosure" or "Visitors-Carriage Enclosure," or "Residents--Admission only" and "Visitors-Admission only,” according to the requirements of the applicant. These tickets will not be ready for issue before January 5.
PUBLIC INSTRUCTION.

The budget of the Ministry of Public Instruction, which in 1904 was fixed at L.E. 120,500, has been raised to L.E. 149,300, an increase of L.E.28,800. Moreover, the National schools and kuttabs have been granted an increase of L.E. 2,000 levied on the payment of fees, bringing the real increase up to a sum of L.E. 31,300, equivalent to an augmentation of not less than 25%. School fees should of course be brought into account and treated as revenue. It is proposed to effect this reform in future years, but it has been found impossible to do so in time for the present budget. The Legislative Council as well as the General Assembly has repeatedly drawn the attention of the Government to the inadequate provision for education. The pressing necessity of nursing the productive possibilities of the country, while at the same time endeavouring to lighten the burden of taxation, added to the danger under the old regime of unduly increasing the ordinary budgetary charges, has hither-to prevented dealing, except on a strictly limited scale, with the needs of the non-productie departments of the Administration. Now, however, when for the first time the financial situation is such as to appear to warrant a more liberal policy, the Government has lost no time in endeavouring, as far as means allowed, to meet the wishes of the national representatives.
It is worth while to explain the present increase in some detail. The new grants are distributed as under :-
Development of elementary primary instruction amongst the poorer olasses ... … L.E. 8,282
II. Development of higher primary instruction... 3,233
III. Increase of teaching staff in girls' schools. .. … 380
IV. Increase of teaching staff in secondary schools …. 2,428
V. Increase for technical and higher education........, 1,015
VI. Increase of salaries.... ..., 10.676
VII. Increase of general expenditure... 5,286

ARMY AND NAVY. (FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
London, December 20.

Major Herbert V. Ravenscroft, Manchester Regiment, lately employed with the Khedive's Army, has taken his retired pay and a commission in a Militia battalion under the usual conditions. Major Ravenscroft has under fifteen years' service, and the last ten were spent in the Egyptian Army, in which he held the local rank of lieutenant colonel. He saw service in the Dongola Expedition 1896 (mentioned in despatches, 4th class Medjidieh; Khedive's medal with two clasps): Nile Expedition 1897, including the action of Abou Hamed (mentioned in despatches, brevet majority, two clasps), and Kitchener's advance on Khartoum 1898, including the battles of Atbara and Omdurmun (mentioned in despatches, British medal; two clasps).

The first-class battleship “Bulwark” (Captain F. T. Hamilton, M.V.O.), flagship of Vice-Admiral Sir C.E. Domville, G.C.V.O., K.C.B., commanding the Mediterranean Fleet, is due to arrive at Devonport to-morrow. She will pay off on January 2 and re-commission with a new crew for the same duty the following day. On returning to her station the "Bulwark” will be refitted at a cost of £5,000.

Sir William H. Manning, K.C.M.G.,C.B., Inspector General of the King's African Rifles, who is at present en route to East Africa for an extensive tour through his command, has been promoted colonel by brevet regimentally. Sir William is a captain of the 61st Sikhs, at Kohat.

Lieutenant Norman M.D. Teacher, the senior subaltern of the Royal Scots Fusiliers, doing duty with the 2nd Battalion at Aldershot, has been selected for service as a company commander in the Egyptian Army. Lieutenant Teacher served with the 2nd Battalion of the Fusiliers in the Boer War, including the actions of Colenso, Vaal Krantz, Tugela Heights, Pieter's Hill, relief of Ladysmith, operations east and west of Pretoria, and in Cape Colony (medal with five clasps).

Major H. O. D. Hickman, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, on giving up the appointment of D.A.A.G. at Devonport, will do duty with the 1st Battalion at Deny till he embarks for Egypt, where he will join the 2nd Battalion at Cairo.
CHRISTMAS SERVICES.
ST. ANDREW'S CHURCH, ALEXANDRIA.

Special services were held in this church on Sunday last. Hymns appropriate to the occasion were sung, and an exceedingly successful and tasteful rendering of the anthem, "Let us now go even unto Bethlehem," was given under the able conductorship of Mr. J. Davies-Bryan. The Rev. H. P. Reid officiated and took as his text, "Behold thy King cometh.” Mrs. John Ross, of Gordon House, sent a very large contribution of flowers and evergreens, and these were used to such advantage in decorating the church that the opinion was freely expressed that the church had never looked nicer.
ENGLISH CHURCH, MANSOURAH.

There were 14 communicants at 7.45 a.m. on 'Xmas Day, and a good attendance at evensong at 6 p.m., during which carols were sung. The church-room was decorated very prettily by many willing hands and all the music at the services was well and heartily performed.

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
DELTA CHURCH SERVICES.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Dear Sir,--Might I, in sending you some notes of our Sunday services at Mansourah and Tantah, hereby make it known that I am very willing to visit any places in the Delta during the week where the special services of a clergyman may be wanted. For those particularly who cannot well attend service at either of the above places on Sundays, and may be desirous of communicating, I shall be very glad to celebrate if the requisite number can be got together.
Yours truly,
T. David C. FIRMINGER,
S. P. G. Chaplain in the Delta. Mansourah, December 27.
HONOUR TO WHOM, ETC.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,--May I solicit the indulgence of a small space in your well-circulated paper to state that on Saturday last (Christmas Eve) my wife went to town shopping and on returning home found she had unfortunately lost her purse containing her watch and a certain amount of money. All hopes of ever recovering it had quite left our winds when it struck me to enquire at the Ramleh Railway Company's head office, thinking she may have dropped it at the station or in a train. I was courteously received by the assistant manager, who, to my astonishment, informed me that a purse, such as I described, had been found in a train, and he at once handed it over to me intact.

Taking into consideration the number of passengers that must have travelled on that day, and the busy time the railway officials must have had, I certainly think it speaks volumes for the vigilance displayed, and moreover, is worthy of all praise for the honesty of the Ramleh Railway Company's personnel.
I am,
Yours very gratefully,
RAMLIAN.
Ramleh, December 27.

THE ALEXANDRIA COAL ASSOCIATION, created on the 18th December, 1894, has completed its 10th anniversary this year. The committee for 1905 were elected at the bi-annual ordinary general meeting, held on the 12th inst., as follows :-Messrs. François Bourgeois, Robert J. Moss, Stelio Petsaly, Roberto J. Rolo, and Roberto Stabile. The retiring president, Mr. Robert J. Moss (after 10 years of office) was, on the 27th inst., re-elected by the committee for the eleventh time, and Mr. Roberto J. Rolo was re-elected vice-president for the second time. The offices of the association are temporarily located at the offices of Messrs. R. J. Moss & Co.

BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE

(Aujourd'hui à midi et demie) Le marché des valeurs & cloturé hier aprèsmidi faible et en mauvaise tendance. Cette situation, due à la baisse des cotons, n'a pu que s'aggraver à la suite de l'aecentuation de cette baisse. Les dernières dépêches de la matinée nous indiquent, en effet, un rec al de 30 à 35 points à New York et de 47 à 55 points à la Nouvelle-Orléans. Cette nouvelle n'a pas manqué d'avoir un effet désastreux sur notre
place et a determiné plusieurs liquidations dans la corbeille des valeurs afin de solder des différences en cotons.

Aussi un désarroi complet règne-t-il de nouveau parmi les spéculateurs et certains d'entre eux commencent à redouter une liquidation de fin du mois laborieuse. Ce serait peut-être le cas si la baisse continuait, mais "un moment à l'autre une reprise peut avoir lieu, témoin ce qui s'est passé au cours de la dernière quinzaine. Il suffirait pour cela d'un amélioration sur les cotons, maintenant surtout que la place se trouve plus ou moins assainis par la récente débâcle de New-York. Au ca; inême ou le recul des cotons augmenterait, on croit (généralement que les cours des valeurs ne Aléobfront plus beaucoup.

La Banque Nationale tombe-22 14, l'A, gricole à 9 7 16, la Daïra à 21 1/8, la Salt & Soda à 37, la Banque d'Athènes à 115, la Filature à 3 4, la Crown Brewery à 219, et l'An. glo-American Nile à 4 5 8.
On est un peu découragé par cette nouvelle réaction. L'entrain fait complètement défaut et les transactions se sont limitées à la Banque Nationale, à la Salt & Soda et à la Banque d'Athènes,
The Egyptian Salt & Soda Company, Ltd.

NOTICE is hereby given, that an Extraordinary General Meeting of the Egyptian Salt & Soda Company, Limited, will be held at the Registered Office of the Company, 6, Old Jewry, E.O., on the twelfth day of January 1905 at 11 o’clock in the forenoon when the subjoined extraordinary and special resolutions will be proposed.

Should the special resolution be passed by the required majority it will be submitted for confirmation as a special resolution to a second extraordinary meeting which will be held on the 27th January 1905, at 11 o’clock in the forenoon at the Registered Office of the Company.
SPECIAL RESOLUTION. That the Articles of Association be altered as follows namely:
a) In Article 34 the words "registered office or the Company's offices in Cairo" shall be substituted for the word "office."
b) In Article 43 (-1-) after the words "except upon" add the words "a request of an allottee on an allotment of shares or upon.”
c) 43 (4). The words "allottees or” shall be added after the words "save as aforesaid."
d) In Article 61 the words "in Cairo" shall be added in the 2nd and last lines after the word "place."
e) In Article 63 the word "to be held in Cairo" shall be added in after the word "meeting."

f) Article 55 after the word "meeting" in the second line and after the word "held” in the last line add the words "in Cairo." • In Article 82 the words "shall be deposited at such place or places in Cairo as shall be appointed for that purpose in the notice convening the meeting” shall be substituted for the words "shall be deposited at the registered office of the Company."

h) In Article 34 the word "not" shall be deleted and add after the words "such warrants" the words "upon depositing the certificate entitling them to vote with the instrument of proxy and the power of attorney (if any) under which it is signed in the manner set forth in article 82."
i) In Article 92 the figures "150" and "300" shall be substituted for the figures "250" and "500" respectively.
j) In Article 102 the words "in Cairo" shall be added after the words "office of the Company."
k) In Article 107 add at the end of the article the words "the meetings of Directors shall be held in Cairo."

1) In Article 114 the words "the business of the Company shall be managed by the Directors, in and from Cairo only” shall be substituted for the words "the management of the business of the Company shall be vested in the Directors."
m) In Article 136 the words "the seal shall be kept in Cairo by the Directors” shall be substituted for the words "the seal shall be in the custody of the Directors.”

n) In article 117 the last sentence shall be cancelled and the following shall be added "The books of account, except in so far as may be otherwise required by the Companies Acts shall be kept at such place in Cairo as the Directors may determine."
0) In Article 150 the words "or Egypt" shall be added in the second and fourth lines after the word "Kingdom."
p) In Article 151 the words "or Egypt" shall be added after the word "Kingdom" and the words “registered office or the office in Cairo" shall be substituted for the word "office."

LAND VALUES IN EGYPT.
BY R. LANG ANDERSON.
The steady rise in the value of land in Egypt is a fact familiar to all residents, but it is often asked - Are not the prices inflated? Will the boom cease? And will a crash come?

The whole economic condition of the country has entirely changed in the last twenty years, and to justify the rise in land values one has only to consider the causes. Taking them in order more or less according to their importance they are found to be:

IRRIGATION. "The many improvements of the irrigation system of the country, notably the Assouan storage dam, the distributary barrages of Assiout, Delta and Zifta, and the remodeling of nearly all the canals, have resulted in an increased, better distributed, and dependable supply of summer water, which, even without other contributory causes, would have greatly increased the value of land. In former years one-third of the land was put under cotton, and a little under summer maize. To-day half is under cotton and half under maize, practically all summer crop. The ultimate wisdom of such intensive farming is questionable at least before the native more thoroughly understands and makes use of manures, both farmyard and artificial. It may be re. marked in passing, that as a matter of fact he is taking to the use of artificial manure supplied in rapidly increasing quantity through the Khedivial Agricultural Society.

POPULATION in any country is one of the most important factors in land valuation. The census of 1900 showed a population in Egypt of 93 million, the increase of the previous decade being 3% per annum. Neither wars nor pestilence and certainly no Malthusian doctrine affect this increase. Cholera two years ago only checked the increase for one year by one halt per cent. Plenteous food, plenteous wage earning. labor enable any native to marry, and that at an early age, so that a century sees five generations instead of the usually accepted standard of three generations in Europe. The women are exceedingly prolific, and but for the excessive infant mortality the country would overflow with population. Roughly, one-third of the deaths are of children under one year, another third of children from 1 to 5 years. It a fair proportion of the children born were raised, the increase of population would be unprecedented.
There are practically no industries in Egypt except agriculture, and the population is fully 1,000 to the square mile of cultivated land.

The population is eating up all the cereal crop produced, and these crops do not even suffice to feed it. Wheat exports are insignificant, bean exports are decreasing, and barley, mostly for brewing, which pays higher than food value, has averaged about 7,000 tons in the last 10 years. But against exports there are imports of flour, rice and maize, making good the statements that the country no more that feeds itself.

COTTON Ten years ago on good land capable of producing 6 kantars of cotton per feddan, the owner planted 1/3 of his area, ran considerable risk of scanty summer water, and had, calculating his whole area in, 2 kantars worth 200 PT. per kantar=E.T. 400. To-day he has 1/2 his area in cotton, or 3 kantars, worth P.T. 350 per kantar=P.T. 1050. His maize gives similar increased returns in quantity, and the price has also advanced in lesser degree.

INVESTMENTS. The prosperous proprietor could not, even if he were willing, find Egyptian Stocks and Shares in which he could place money as a judicious permanent investment, giving good return for his capital. The Market is very sensitive, even trivial transactions send shares up or downlEven if £50,000 of shares could be bought at market quotation, distributing the investment over companies with a steady record, it would probably not yield over 4 % return. In most of the companies with a future, that future has already been discounted at a price disproportionate to the prospects.
The native, however, will not invest in companies nor in Government Funds. That could have been done formerly on a basis of 6% or 7 % exclusive of the capital value
since accrued. Increased cost of investments throw people back on land.

CHEAP MONEY. With the advent of the Agricultural Bank a new era opened for the fellah, rendering him independent of the village usurer. The fellah can get his small loans at 9 %. The usurer bas w displace the lender who got 10 %. and he in turn the mortgagees who had 7 %. The latter must buy land, for the great insurance companies of Britain have entered the field. Their uvested capital is some 400 million pounds sterling and even a small proportion of this means much in Egypt. Even five years ago. sound mortgages were 7 % to 8 %. The insurance companies take 5 $ % to 65 % according to circumstances. Even Australia is enquiring into money lending in Egypt. There is dislocation of the loan market all through and people who are ousted find purchase of land of increasing value, better than mortgage of which capital value is stationary.
AREA OF LAND.

Egypt has roughly 6,000,000 feddans cultivated area. Even if the great lacrustine Lakes of Meuzaleb, Buurlos, Edku, and Ma reotis were cultivated, as well as the waste lands of the interior of the Delta, the additional area would not exceed 1,500,000 teddaus.

That is, the possible addition to Egypt proper is 25 %. If the work were taken in hand tomorrow it would take 20 years to accomplish, an addition of 1 1% per annum for a population increasing 3 % per annum. Till actually starved out the fellateen population will not emigrate to the Sudan. The ordinary fellah will not even go a few miles from his own village so long as he can make ends meet comfortably. There are people enough for all the land Egypt bas or ever cau bave.

SALE OF LANDS. The Daira Sanieh have sold off all their lands. The State Dumains are holding firmly their much reduced area and only sell in small plots to natives at a high price. Their sales are limited to a certain sum, about £200,000 per annum, therefore the higher

the price per feudan the less the area sold. They are putting little land on the market. Government waste lauds, formerly sold in thousands of feudans at mere nominal rates, can now be had with dithculty. The large Tland companies have increased their prices and are somewhat indifferent to sales unless the prices are good. Private proprietors are just as suiff in price.
PEACEABLE POSSESSION

is essential to the owner of land. In Egypt a sound title can be had, registered in the Tribunals, but what is equally important to the tellah is enure freedom from the unlawful exaction of dishonest officials. That backsheesh suill exists everybody knows, but it does not and cannot attain the proportions of serious squeezing. It miuor irrigation officials get a lew pounds from & village, it is paid in the hopes of getting rather more than their rights, not w save their crop from destruction. Caual rotations are noticed Lin the official juurual, and whilst there may be a little tampering with the programme, the minor employee who tries it is very likely to come w grief.

The tax gatherer is now no terror. He has to present the "wird” showing amount of tax and when due. i Corvée is practically abolished. Natives make no concealment now of possessing money, well knowing that it cannot be extorted from them. The possession of land and meaus makes him a man to be respected in his village, not to be marked down for extortion.
(To be continued.)

HELOUAN RACES.

In connection with the H.S.C. First Winter Meeting, which will take place at Helouan on the race-course adjoining the Tewfik Palace Hotel on Saturday next, the management of the hotel 188ue Tewfik race coupons at P.T. 55 for visitors and P.T. 40 for ladies, to include: 1st class rail to Helouan, luncheon at the Tewfik Palace, entrance to grand stand and paddock, afternoon tea in members' enclosure, and 1st class rail to Cairo.

These coupons are on sale at the booking office (Cairo) Bab-el-Louk, but to facilitate matters for the public and avoid the usual rush at the station on race day, arrangements have been made for them to be also sold on any day previous to the 31st December at Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt) Ltd., Shepheard's Hotel, the Bristol Hotel, the Eden Palace Hotel, and Stephenson and Co., Opera-square. The club has great expectations of a bumper meeting, so that by taking coupons visitors save trouble and expense.

The entries for the various events are well filled, and prospects of a good day's sport are excellent. We hear that a large number of luncheon parties have been arranged for by residents and others at the Grand and the Tewtik Palace Hotels. The enclosure and railings are now completed, and the place looks very trim and attractive. Three trains are arranged to run to the H. S. C. platform, opposite the entrance to the enclosure, leaving Cairo (Bab-el-Louk) at 11.30, 12.10, 1.15.
The lotteries will be held to-morrow at 9 p.m. at the Tewfik Palace Hotel. The Delta Light-Railway Company is making all arrangements to cope with the increased traffic on the day of the races.
. (Babel-Lorance to th. . 8. c
RACING AT KHARTOUM.
FIRST WINTER MEETING.

The First Winter Meeting at Khartoum, held under K.S.C. Rules, took place on the 17th inst, and passed off most successfully, the band of the 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade greatly adding to the enjoyment of the afternoon's sport. Mr. Trafford's stable provided the winners of three events, whilst representatives of the Shendi stable (Mr. Rome and Capt. Grant) were prominent on more than one occasion, notably in the race for the Governor General's Cup, the big event of the day, which Mr. Rome's "dark" horse Bill Bailey won in hollow fashion from the much-fancied Ghadban, late the property of Capt. A. Pirie. The following are the results :

THE PONY PLATE-Value P.T. 700, 2nd to receive P.T. 200, 3rd to save his stake. For Arab ponies, weight for age and inches with penalties, raised 7 lbs. 14 bands to carry 11 st. 7 lbs. One mile. Mr. S. W. Trafford's g.a.b. White Heather,
aged. 11.7. Major Dawson. Capt. W. H. Drake's g.a.h. Tim, aged. 11.7
Owner. Capt. Grant and Mr. Rome's g.a.b. Inshallah,
aged. 11.3. Capt. Meyrick. Capt. Morant's b.a.h. Gamil, aged. 11.7.Owner.0 Capt. Charlton's b.a.h. Sinbad. aged. 11.7.
Owner. Mr. Rome's ch.a.h. Mr. Dooley, 6 yrs. 11.3.
Mr. Blacker.
White Heather and Gamil made the running for about half the distance, when the former drew out and won as he liked by 2 lengths.
Totalisator paid P.T. 27.

“ALL THE BRITISH FLEET SHOULD USE VI-COCOA ”
Mr. C. ATTRILL, Leading Seaman, 15 Mess, H.M.S. "London,"

Mediterranean, Plateau, Greece, writes: - "As I am leading hand of the Boat Deck of this Battleship, and exposed to all contrasts of weather, in the early morning watches, afterwards being away all day deep-sea mining without the opportunity of obtaining any refreshments, I felt, on returning at night, utterly exhausted. Having heard of the great benefits derived from Vi-Cocoa I resolved to give it a trial, and have greatly benefited by doing so. Now I feel equal to standing any bardships. It would be only justice to you to make what use you like of this letter, as it may make Vi. Cocoa more widely known amongst the Fleetmen in general who are exposed as I am to all contras 8 of weather."

div.p: N.B. – Ne seront admis dans les deux trains No 3 et 24, que les voyageurs porteurs de billets de 1re et 2e classe seulement et les abonnés à ces deux classes. Le train No 16 ne s'arrêtera pas les Dimanches au garage Cozzika. – Le train No 22 s'arrêtera les Dimances à Massarah au lieu du train No 18.

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
